participants.participant: José Ignacio Sanchez Galán, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
José Sáinz Armada, Chief Financial Officer and Director of Non Energy Business

plist.p: Good morning. We're going to begin our presentation for the First Half of 2009. But before I begin, I would like to mention that José Luis San Pedro is not with us today. José Luis just one week ago had a small accident and he has broken his leg and he is still recovering. So, we wish him a very fast recovery. Let's hope he will be back with us at the next presentation of results and will continue to give us his wisdom.
Chairman, Mr. Ignacio Galán has the floor.
Good morning. Thank you for your attendance here, and those of you who are also here with us through the telephone or the webpage. Today, the presentation will be structured as follows.

First of all, I'll talk about the major aspects of the first half and then José Sainz will get into greater depth in the economic and financial results. And finally, as always we'll have some conclusions and then we'll get into the Q&A session.

The first semester of 2009, IBERDROLA has shown its capacity to manage any environment and get positive results. And so, in this situation characterized by a strong fall in demand which we hadn't seen in all my years in this business and also a fall in prices as a result of the macroeconomic situation, we have increased EBITDA by 4.7% to €3.43 billion, and 3.4% rise in cash flow, which stands at €2.35 billion and net profit is over 1.5 billion.

In this first half of 2009 the main markets have continued to show a growing trend – down fall in energy demand with falls that had not been seen since the 70s and are ranging from 7% in Spain to 4% in the United States.

We have to highlight, however, that in the last month and a half we are starting to see the first signs of deceleration of the fall in demand, especially in Spain. The falls in the month of June and July have moderated to reaching 2 and 3% compared to the 7% in June and if this trend continues, we can – it could be a certain improvement, especially in Q4 of this year.

So even in this environment, the mix of generation in IBERDROLA has maintained production of the company at a same level of last year at 70,000 gigawatts. To this wind energy has grown greater hydro production and recuperation of production with coal in terms of distributed energy. The integration of energy has brought us to 100,000 gigawatts in one semester – one half year. That's an increase of 14% compared to June of last year. More than 50% of this amount has been distributed outside of Spain. Most -- more than half is distributed outside of Spain – produced and distributed outside of Spain.

Now, we've also getting – delve deeper into different aspects of the company optimizing the situation of the Group here with the short-term and improving its position in the positive change focusing on three fundamental areas, realization effort – additional effort into improved efficiency, which we will talk about more later, strengthening of the financial structure of the Group and the proactive management of regulatory aspects with a view to contributing to an improvement in the existing frameworks in the countries where we are carrying out our operations.

Now beginning with operational efficiency, in the first half of 2009 we reduced the operational – net operational cost by 7.5% excluding Energy East, which was not with us last year. To achieve this we've concentrated on businesses that have incorporated recently to the Group, especially ScottishPower.

Once again, the British company had reduced its cost, which fell by 13% in costs, and their expenses over gross margin are at 29%, 200 basis – improvement of 200 basis points. Iberdrola Renovables is also making progress in this sense and in June improved by 8% in the ratio of operational expenses over and – per megawatt. In the first quarters we continued to – continue making headway, especially in the United States.

In terms of the balance management, Q2 2009, we carried out different initiatives to strengthen our financial structure. First of all, we've continued with a strict control of our investments, not only applying rigorous profitability criteria but also seeking efficiencies in the field such as procurement, basically in new business. In addition, we've advanced in our divestment plan with operations reaching €1.3 billion, more than half. And so we – and we've got capital gains of €223 million in the results of our Q1.

Also in June, we carried out a capital increase of €1.32 billion in operation. And that we closed successfully in just a few hours. And finally we've increased our liquidity up to €10.6 billion – the financials that we'll talk about in just a minute. So all of these measures are clearly visible in the accounts of June 2009. The financial debt has been reduced by more than 2 billion to 26.4 billion and owned funds are now over €28 billion. With that the solvency of the company has been strengthened. The leverage has been reduced to 48% excluding the tariff deficit and the cash flow ratio over debt is at 17.5%.

In the Q1 results we talked about our determination to defend the interest of our shareholders and the recovery of the tariff deficit and I predicted that the decision would be announced as soon. And on 30 April, the company did announce a series of measures that, as you know, allow for the creation of the totally liberalised markets which were supported by the parliament on the 24th of June. If my memory serves me right, 80% of the consumption is in the market and the remaining 20% is subject to additional tariffs that do not generate a deficit and are not unfair competition in the market. No one could imagine that this would happen after eight years of struggle.

Now in terms of the tariff deficit, it will completely disappear by 2013 with a securitization fund has also been created that will allow for the early payment of the current deficit, with the guarantee of the Treasury. Right now all of the necessary documents for this securitization are at the Council of State after going through the Treasury and the Ministry of Industry and over the next couple of days this subject will be ready to go directly to the Cabinet for approval and therefore implemented in Q4 of this year. There is also a framework for the last reserved tariff and the social bonus for certain groups.

And finally, and this is also important, Royal Decree 11/2007 has been eliminated. This was the CO2 emission clawbacks because it was more distorting than anything else for the energy generation market.

So this new framework is an opportunity for IBERDROLA. And the company now is currently making a considered effort to adapt to that and doing that as quickly as possible. Now this effort is in terms of intensifying sales initiatives, focused on the high-end customers and this connection. Right now IBERDROLA is signing more than 25,000 contracts per week and has doubled its portfolio since beginning of the year.

The company is also focused on a series of initiatives to assure orderly transition to the new market. We're carrying out an intense campaign of meetings with public organizations, association – consumer associations and the media. We have reinforced our call centers and we've adapted our systems.

Over the last several months, we have also made significant headway in regulation of two of our main markets in United States and the United Kingdom. In the United State, the tariff review of our distributors in the state of New York continues its course and in this connection, we're working to achieve a framework that allow us to meet the important investment challenges and improve the quality that that state requires.

In terms of renewable energies, with the regulation implementing the so-called, that has been put into place. This will allow us to obtain around $500 million in 2009. This measure of the North American government is an incentive to our investment in that country which could reach $6 billion between 2009 and 2013. This is in the area of renewables that will give us access to $2 billion in grants over the next several years, and gives a much our value to our pipeline more than 220,000 megawatts in that country.

In the UK the national climate change strategy has been published and the government speaks of a scenario for 2020 where emissions should be reduced by 34% compared with the 1990 levels. And to do that they'll need to invest very strongly into the IBERDROLA technologies and nuclear and wind energy where they will continue with the remuneration system up until 2037. And this will result in bottlenecks that often happen in terms of permits – permits and access to the grid.

And the – in terms of coal infrastructures, we're working on our technology to capture the CO2 emissions there. The ambition of the government is to achieve these technologies. And they will contribute 40% to production in 2020 compared with the 15% in 2008. So the growth will come by renewable energies that will account for 30% of the production by the end of this period. Also the document also is going to improve the electric grids. This is very important in the UK which are now being – the regulatory framework is being reviewed and this reflects the need for strong investment in the UK.

Results from the first half of 2009 reflect – reflects its positive impact of the management effort that I have been talking about. So in June of 2009 EBITDA, the Group reached €3.43 billion with an increase of 5% despite the fact, as you know, the new businesses of the Group which contribute greatly to this growth are very seasonal. Also in 2009, the pound has suffered devaluation compared to the euro and has an effect on the results of the Group. So the results of the management of the different businesses in local currency reflect a growth, which is close to actually 10% if you work with a currency change.

So the solidness of IBERDROLA is a result of the strategic – of the strategy of the Group as you can see in its portfolio. The increase in the relative weight of the regulated and renewable business, which are less exposed the effects of change in economic cycles have allowed us to continue improving our results. Even our liberalised business has – has been – has – had only a very limited decline. Thanks to the efficiency in Spain and the UK I early spoke about.

And finally, cash flow has grown by 3.4% reaching €2.35 billion. And net profit is over 1.5 billion in a half of year that in comparative terms affected by the capital gains of the Q1 of the pervious year.
Now, I'll give the floor to José Sáinz Armada, who will get into greater depth in the different financial issues.

Thank you very much, Chairman. Good morning. As is our want, we will not tell you about the more salient aspects of the profit and loss account for the first half. And then we'll look at the main points in our main areas of business and I'll wind up with an analysis of the Group's financial situation.
It should be said that this account has been affected by integrating Energy East into the Group in the first half of the year that had an impact on the figures, we'll be telling about.

As the Chairman has said, EBITDA is up 4.7% to €3.4 billion but I would like to stress that if you exclude Energy East EBITDA is falling by only 2.4%, which shows the strength of IBERDROLA'S business model in an environment where there is very strong falls in demand and in tariffs.

Income is up 9%. In Spain, there is a loss in demand and in prices. I'll go into further detail later. We've registered Ordinary Regime production decrease of only 3.3%, which is compared very favorably with the system as a whole, where the fall is around 15%. Despite the fall in the value of the pound sterling, ScottishPower has become the component to the Group, giving us the greatest part of our growth. This despite depreciation of 17% in the value of pound sterling, 31% of our income comes from ScottishPower.

Renewable business, growth 1.1% up to €948 million. In Latin America, our business has fallen by 27% due to tariff reviews in Brazil. Non-energy down 14% due to slowdown in business – in the real estate business. Energy East is providing €1.7 billion, 13% of the total of income. As to procurement, has grown – of energy has grown 9% to €7.4 billion. ScottishPower, 38% of the total; energy is 13%. The Spanish business is 26% with a downcrease of 7% year-on-year.

Our gross margin is expanding 10.9% to €5.4 billion. Traditional energy business in Spain, 37% of this gross margin, up to €2.002 billion, 21% is liberalised business and 16% in the regulated sector. Renovables and the international power mix explain the change in the makeup of the Group's gross margin. Renovables or renewables are supplying 15%; ScottishPower 20%, which is €1.055 billion, Energy East 13%, Latin America is 9% of our gross margin, as I say. If you take the basic margin, which includes the net effect arising from emission rights, it is up by 8.9%, 2 percentage points less than the gross margin I told you about. This is due to the down – to the fall in prices of CO2 rights.

The gross profit includes the negative impact from the emission rights consumed, €242 million, 69 million in Spain and 173 million in ScottishPower. The basic profit margin can be achieved – can be figured out by adding the gross margin to the positive effect of €144 million coming from free rights received, 55 million in Spain and 89 million in ScottishPower. These are put into the account as less expenditure.

The operative – the net operative expenditure is up 19% to €1.776 billion. If we exclude Energy East, which is 22% of the total, then this operative net expenditure is down 7.5%. The main drivers in this drop in our net operative expenditure is staff including Energy East, 4% down to €1,776 million.

Our national energy business is level because we have (18.02) restraint. Renovables is up only 2.4%. I should also underscore the downturn of 21% in net staff expenditure in ScottishPower, which shows how efficient they've been in decreasing such expenditure. And this is 8% this effect, if you rule out the exchange rate effect. In Latin America, there is a downturn of 24% in staff costs due to efficiency, et cetera.

Our external energy services, excluding Energy East, our down 10.6% to €702 million. There are certain non-recurrent effects accounting for 70 million. If we exclude insurance, et cetera, if we exclude them, the reduction will be 1.6%. Levies, up 4.3% to €385 million. Energy East accounts for €99 million. This is compensated for by a lower provision for a clawback of emission rights, which is €98 million less than in the first half of 2008 due to decrease in the price of these emission rights. This provision covers both assigned and non-assigned facilities.

It has to be underscored also the Royal Decree Law 11/2007 has been announced (19.38). So it is not going to have any effect as of the 1st of July 2009. With regard to IBERDROLA, most of this provision for a clawback in emission rights corresponds to non-assigned – to power plants that have not been assigned any emission rights.
Group EBITDA would have grown 13% if we were to exclude the impacts beyond the normal development of the business, which shows that business is developing well despite the market environment.

We've eliminated €71 million of non-recurring expenditure, including the net operative expenditure of the company, when it comes to the heading, Other Operating Income. But we've also got accountancy adjustments to the tune of 121 million, 99 million coming from the effect of transferring results of Energy East to U.S. GAAP and then transferring from GAAP to the IFRS standards and 22 million due to recalculating the (20.47) of renewables were dealt with.

There is also the exchange rate which cost us 123 million from the EBITDA, and a mark-to-market effect cost us 82 million. But we hope that IFRS and the exchange rate for the pound sterling will work in our favor in the future and this mark-to-market effect will change in the future also; that's to be hoped.

The Group's EBIT is down 1.2% to €2.338 billion due to an increase of 20% in the depreciation and amortization heading to 1.097 billion. Amortizations, D&A, €1.066 million, including €104 million from Energy East; PPA, 110 million. The Group's financial result is up 28.3% to minus €605 million. This is due to the greater expenditure and the debt, which is up 44%. This is a result in part of the accumulated tariff deficit and the debt – indebtedness associated with the purchase of Energy East. We've been able to expand the spreads on our debt. We have taken advantage of drops in interest rates, and we've brought about a drop in the financial cost of 50 base points.

Profit before tax is down 20% to €1.981 billion. When it comes to non-recurring results, at June 2009, we have capital gains of €223 million, largely a result of selling 10% of our holding in Gamesa and disinvesting from energy assets in Chile. We have not included the sale of regasification plants. This is 320 – sorry, €312 million less than the figure for June 2008. And the results for equivalents are 25 million, which is 34 million less than in June 2008. This is largely due to Gamesa. But as in June 2008, they have made a contribution to non-recurrent 25 million as a result of the sale of its solar energy business.

Net profit, down 23% to €1.506 billion, and this drop is somewhat more than the drop in the profit before tax, 20.4%, due to the greater effective tax rate, 21.1%, in comparison with 19.0% in the first half of 2008. But as the Chairman has stressed, we have an increase in operative cash flow of 3.4% up to €2.355 billion.

Now the highlights of our different business areas, and I'll start with the liberalised business in Spain. There our results have been affected by the following points. As I said, our production is down by only 3.3% in an environment where the demand in general has dropped considerably, 6.4%, and system production has dropped 14.9%. But our production dropped as I say only 3.3%. Increased hydro production 7%, compensating for the fall in nuclear production minus 8%. We should stress also that there has been a fall of 35% in the average Spanish pool price to €40 per megawatt-hour. But our combined cycles are based upon mid merit. So we are getting higher prices than you can see on this slide, because the mid merit is a higher price, and we are getting higher prices also for complementary service markets.

Now, the unit average cost of our conventional thermal fuel is down 13% to €46.7 per megawatt-hour. This includes gas where we have a time delay of three to six months. So there'll be a greater effect later on this year and also includes the decreased cost of CO2. EBITDA of our Spain liberalised business sector is down 7.2% to €719 million as a result of the increases in generation costs. We have lower prices and lower demand, which was related to that. And against that backdrop, our net operating cost is – has been contained. It is a growth of 5%. And the turnover includes 59 million of repaid capacity payments, which have been compensated in part by the 96 million put into the account due to clawback for CO2 emission rights.

Now as to the perspectives for the liberalised part of our business activities in Spain, there are a number of different factors which will give rise to different kinds of effects. Firstly, in the second half of the year, there'll be no more CO2 clawbacks. And secondly, with regard to the demand and price environment, whereas there has been a decrease in both demand and prices in the first half of this year, it is to be expected that by the fourth quarter we should see increase – we should see signs of recovery in both demand and tariffs.

The EBITDA of our regulated sector in Spain is up by 9.1%. This improves the – upon the result of our gross margin, which was only 8.7%, despite the fact that the net operating expenditure is up. There's been expenditure due to hurricanes, tornadoes in particular. This increase in the gross margin up to €842 million is a reflection of the increase of regulated tariffs under 2009.

Installed capacity, 10,000 megawatts, an increase of 26% year-on-year. But our capacity to produce has grown 24% to 10.585 gigawatt-hour. Average load factor, 27%. Efficiency has increased, because our cost per megawatt is down 8.2% and the average price has come down 15%. But in the second half of the year, there is prospectives of improvement, because there has been a coverage agreement for Spain since July 2009 for a period of two years at a price of €46 per megawatt hour. And we have to add to that the bonus, which should give us an estimated price of between 85 and €90 watts – euros per megawatt hour.

Now, I have to stress the way – different way in which PTC should be accounted for in the first half of 2008 and through the first half of 2009, which means that basically EBITDA has been increased 6% rather than 1.8% that we've reported. The brute – I'm sorry – gross margin is up 6.3% to €828 million. If we were to use homogeneous accounting standards, we'll be talking about a growth of 10% there. I should again stress the containing effect we've had on our staff expenditure.

With regard to ScottishPower, in local currency, its gross margin was £1.021 billion, up 11% in homogeneous terms, despite decreased production and demand in the general environment. The net operating cost improved by 13%. This net operating cost in local currency was down 3%. EBITDA ScottishPower, excluding the impact of the MtM, £737 million, the 135 million due to the exchange rate variation means that EBITDA is down 7.7% in euros to €829 million.

More details now on the ScottishPower as follows. Production down 4.9% due to less use of combined-cycle plant used highly flexibly. Energy transmitted down 5.3%, in line with the mean decrease in the UK, only limited impact on income. Better domestic rates in retail compensated for also by an increase in the average cost of fuel.

I'd also stress, efficiency and synergy well managed in this business, 75% of the objectives were determined after the acquisition of this company. So, the ratio between net operating cost divided by brute – gross profit is increasing by 31%, or rather from 31% in the first half of '08 to 29% in the first half of '09.
Energy Wholesale & Retail is something that has contributed €730 million. Energy Retail has contributed €415 million and Canada and Corporation provide €21.4 million of the remaining EBITDA.

Energy East has made a contribution of €235 million to the Group's EBITDA under IFRS standards. Energy East business is highly seasonal, because it makes 65% of its turnover in the first and fourth quarters of the year. We sell less energy in quarters two and three, because the climate's better than – which is when we carry out maintenance and the net operating cost goes up. Furthermore, this business is affected by accountancy corrections as a result of transferring from U.S. GAAP to IFRS. This has had a negative effect of €98.6 million in this half of the year.

Now using the tariff assets under NIIF standards means that this volatility in energy, it accounts if you use a cash basis. The basic effect is that price of sales to the end customer have come down, whereas provision costs have not done the same. Now this is – this difference is known as NBC, non-bypassable charges. That's accepted by the regulator for future tariffs, but not under U.S. GAAP – or rather, it is accepted under GAAP, but not under IFRS. And this will be charged in the second half of the year.

In Latin America, there has been a fall of 1.7% to €423 million, that's lower than that registered gross margin of 6.8%, that thanks to the positive development of net operating cost which reduced by 25%, in line with the efficiency management carried out by the Group. In this half, Brazil and Mexico have opposite effects. Brazil contributed 231 million to EBITDA, a fall of 11% affected by the tariff review for the period 2008-2012, a reduction which is called Parcel B with a 12.1% in Coelba and 6.5% in Cosern and 8% in Celpe.

And then a slight improvement of demand of the distributors 1.2% on average and a negative effect of the exchange rate with a devaluation year-on-year of the Brazilian real of 13%. Mexico has contributed 192 million to EBITDA and the effect by – had a positive effect of exchange rate with the year-on-year with the dollar of 13% and the business also has been behaving better than a year ago due to the good yield of the plants.

And EBITDA, non-energy EBITDA has fell by 33.6% reaching €140 million due to the lower activity of the real estate business. Engineering has a portfolio of €2.7 billion and includes the recent project that was just won in Lithuania, €328 million. And we have invoicing of €622 million and continues developing its activity in a satisfactory manner despite the deceleration in the world economy.

In terms of financing, beginning with the tariff deficit in the balance sheet, in the first half of 2009, the tariff insufficiency accumulated for IBERDROLA through December 2008 was €2.36 billion. Now during the first half of 2009, we obtained funds of €132 million and a new tariff insufficiency was generated for IBERDROLA of €642 million. So at the close of the first half of 2009, the tariff insufficiency is €2.87 billion.

However, within the framework – of the regulatory framework that we – the Chairman mentioned, there has been important changes in terms of possible payment of this through Royal Decree 6/2009 and will have a positive effect on the balance sheet and debt – Group debt. So we are working now with the – with those deficits. And this should – we should have effects of this by the end of the year.

Now, continuing with the analysis of the financial situation and the – those significant improvement in net debt, which – for this second – Q2 of this year, I think end of the Q1 the net debt was €28.5 million. The net cash flow before divestments increased by €1 billion. Once again, the sale of the regasification plant announced for a price of €200 million will not to be – will not be paid until the end of 2009.

There is also a capital increase of €1.3 billion. The tariff deficit increased by €240 million in the quarter and cash flow generated has covered the investments without having any impact on the debt. So we've decreased the debt from – more than 2 billion, and right now we stand at €26.44 billion. Until the end of year we hope to continue with the divestment plan announced in Q1 to end up with a net debt between 25 and €26 billion.

Our own funds at the close of the first half of 2009 were €28.2 billion, greater than the 26.1 billion at the close of the – of Q1 after the effect of the capital increase and the increase corresponding to the non-distributed assets and this 200 in capital gains and divestments. The leverage therefore is at 48.4%, 3.8 points lower than the 52.2 that we had at the end of March. If we include the tariff deficit, the leverage will be at 51%, three points below last – this time last year.

The rest of the financial ratios also have improved significantly in line with the commitments required by the rating agencies. FFO over net debt has improved by 17.5% and the RCF over net debt improved to 12.2%. These ratios are within the ranges A3/A that are required by the agencies.

In terms of the breakdown of debt by financing resources, we have proper diversification. In terms of the debt structure by currencies and where the percentage of the debt minimizes leverage and ratios and helps with solvency. And so the debt in euros is 46%, and in pounds and dollars around 25% of the debt.

In terms of the debt by interest rates, in the first half of 2009, we've increased to 47.5% in variable interest rate of the total amount of debt. We should also point out our liquidity, right now we have €10.6 billion of liquidity in this – available lines and this covers all of the needs for liquidity from 2009 and part of 2010.

And to finish up, I am going to talk about the maturity of the debt. The average maturity rate is almost six years. And now the Chairman will conclude this presentation with a presentation of results.

Thanks very much, José. Having looked at these results of the first half I would like to very briefly get into the perspectives of the Group for 2009. And we need to differentiate very clearly here the two quarters that we have left in this year, given the seasonal nature of the new businesses and the evolution of the different energy variables and macroeconomic variables in terms of demand will be characterized by certain moderation while as from October there will be greater recovery due to seasonal factors, as well as the consolidation of the reactivation of energy consumption that we're starting to see.

Also, production will also be affected by demand and by the – and by distribution typical of wind energy throughout the year, meaning Q3 is greater and Q4 are greater than the first half of the year. So the wholesale prices will be less – lower as is normal and will recover as from October.

And finally, the measures taken to reduce the volatility of the markets will mean that impact of the raw materials market will be reduced compared to the previous years. And we have to look at the positive effect that this chapter had on Q3 last year and had that positive effect at the end of the year. So with all of this, we expect that the results for the end of the year will reach – will have a good operational growth and stability in net gains.

And just to conclude, the figures that we presented today show the commitment that we have with the comprehensive integration of the company with all of the macroeconomic situations. So in the first half of 2009, especially just over the last several months, we've implemented series of initiatives focused on optimizing our results and preparing the company for improvement in this situation, with increased efficiency through control – our cost control measures focused on our business in the UK and in Renewables. And over the upcoming months we'll continue delving deeper into these and will implement other new programs, especially internationally and especially in the United States as I mentioned at the beginning.

We've also shown our financial flexibility which has allowed us to improve our balance sheet through three different measures. Strict investment control and divestment of non-strategic assets and capital increase. And with that, our financial structure shows ratios that we think will allow the Group to proceed very comfortably within our credit rating.

And finally, and to guarantee sustainable growth, IBERDROLA has put its energy on its new businesses in the United States where there are magnificent expectations and very good aid as well. In this sense, the administration, the American administration has fostered our investments in the electricity sector to improve the economic situation there. So in this connection you can all be rest assured that the men and women working in this company are going to continue working pretty hard to maximize our results and benefit of all shareholders.
Thanks very much.
Now is the Q&A session. . Now we're going to start with the questions from the room here. Please raise your hand and we'll be happy to pass you a microphone.

Good morning from the Citi Group. Just two or three questions. The first with regard to the tariff that you talked about working on this in Q4. And we're still at 600 some million, so your hope is to completely eradicate this, or will that also go into 2010?

The second question has to do with the PPA announced yesterday with Iberdrola Renovables. I'd like to know what was the rationale behind this contract at a €46 per megawatt price with the prices that we see on the forward market in Spain.

And also, I would like to ask a question with regard to generation. Can you give us a little bit more information or the liberalised activity and give us an update on the forward markets – the forward sales in the different markets in terms of percentages of production. And what price levels are you signing these agreements at?

Well the deficit that I talked about before, the first thing I'd like to mention, I'd like to first apologize because I said that the Royal Decree, it wasn't 30, I think it was six days later than my prediction, so I apologize for that.

The second thing, as I mentioned before, right now the Treasury has come up with the Royal Decree for this. It's sent this to the Ministry of Industry, they have validated it. So right now it's going to go to the cabinet and the Council of State will look at it -- to look in this through an emergency procedure. So I think in a week or ten days the Council – State Council will return this. So the government cabinet, in August, if they meet, can approve that. So that means that everything will be ready to set up the committee to deal with this by the end of the year.

So the greatest expectations that we have right now is that before the end of year all of that money will be declared. Then these funds will be – will start out for 10 – amount of €10 billion and this will also cover the funds from 2009. But the recent measures that the government has taken as from July 2 by approving, I think it was the raising the fees in July. This means that the maximum deficit for this year will be the amounts that are contained in that Royal Decree. So these are in line with what was passed by Parliament about decreasing tariff deficit. So expectations, everything could be finished up this year. Everything is being implemented and so things are moving as fast as they possibly can.

Just in a few words, I mentioned this yesterday and I will reiterate. In the last meeting that we had in the presentation of results of renewables, there was an investor who asked us why we had PPAs in renewables around the world and here in Spain we had this volatility where we had much better elements to get certain costs in renewables, everything having to do with the deviations around €4 that it was costing – costing this management. We could have benefited from those 3 or €4 that we had on those deviation costs and that's what we're – that's what we're trying to do.

So once again, the investors and analysts, you have very good ideas and make us think. So we do have PPAs in the U.S. and Europe, in the UK and in Spain the question was, why don't we? Since when you have the best conditions to be able to resolve this issue, especially with the cost, the Group was losing 3 or €4 that third parties were taking. So the analysis – a thorough analysis was done by our renewable and IBERDROLA teams and I'm sure they did their work very well. They've analyzed the forward prices with all the limitations that we have there, but there are €4 that were lost. That's the first major message.

The second message is that price of 46 is not a theoretical price. But for me, this is the average price of energy sales between 2007 and 2008. We're talking about a price over the last two years that we applied for the futures. And the price of the next two years has a review formula. If the prices go very much higher in renewables then we'll benefit, if they go below, renewables, then we'll be a little bit penalized. But the model is basically on those €4 that were lost.

On the first question, on the liberalised segment, I'm looking at the figures for the last quarter of last year. Connecticut is – we've had some disappointment in Connecticut and we're in the process of looking at appealing the two decisions that we recently received and also refiling as quickly as we can. And refiling for ROEs in excess of 10%.

The Group on 2010, we haven't started. I don't have any figures. We haven't started looking at those perspectives. They're not being brewed up yet. So November at the earliest. On the first question, Paco? (57.46)

As for exposure, as I said earlier, it's around – it was close to nil, because what we haven't sold or reserved to sell, we'll sell on the complementary markets where the prices we get are totally different. As to what it would take to increase the prices, well prices. Thermal prices were a response to demand and to the production under the general regime and a special regime, basically. And they also depend upon commodities' prices and on the level of competition spreads, et cetera. And if you take that whole mass of factors, we're looking at the second half of this year, and we reckon that the prices will be where they are now. Although in the press you can see reports of 34, when that's adequately weighted, that's around 40.

The point is that most of our production has been sold up elsewhere than on the spot market. Two clients who are of course paying higher prices than on the spot market, and when the spot prices go up to 75, these clients will be paying less. So as always the spot price is a benchmark, the forward price is another benchmark, but in practice each kilowatt hour is paid for at the price that the client and the vendor feel appropriate.
40% or 50% above OTC right now. Question from Virginia?

Paco, tell us something about forward sales for 2010?
Well, we've already told them...

We think demand will develop, but we're going to have to see which way and how it will develop over the next few months. One or two months' change is not – in trend is not sufficient to forecast next year, so the commodities' prices plus demand scenario will give us an impression of net prices for next year. So in the States we'll start to take measures to cut costs, but right now they're still on the back of an envelope. So we'll see. I'd like to give you more precise figures once we've got the scenarios defined.

As to the social bonus, I think it's only around 3% of the total energy we sell and Paco correct me if I'm wrong. So it will depend upon the tariffs for next year, but on the face of it, when it comes to the volume of energy sold under the social bonus, it's really quite limited. So unless the prices zoom up, I don't think it's going to have much of an impact. And I think that under the social bonus, the price is around 60 or 70, is it?
Bit less?

Around 40. So that's more or less market prices. So it's going to depend upon future prices, but the point is that the volume is low. As to selling assets, we're going to continue. September, October, is kind of the period you're looking at.
Okay.

Good morning, yes. Pablo Cuadrado from Merrill Lynch. Good morning. Many of my questions were already answered. Just two quick ones. One has to do with a load factor of the cycles in Spain with a very good results compared to what we've seen in other markets and good volumes. And the second has to do with the dividend to this capital increase. Could you tell us what your ideas, in terms of the dividend for this year, if you'll maintain the same payout as last year in absolute terms?
Paco, would you talk about the spot spread please?

The load factor of the combined cycles, as the speaker said, around 30, 37% and has been better than the decrease in our competitors. We haven't undergone that same decrease. In terms of gas, everything has been sold for 2009. All of our commitments are sold, therefore. We'll have to see if we have an opportunity to buy on the spot market to resell, but the contractor gas has been sold. In terms of the spreads, this year and next year are not good years for thermal energy. The spread – the strict spread, I'm talking about the margin, the variable margin for management, is around four, €5 per megawatt hour. And then when we bear in mind the fixed revenues, it improves a little bit, but this is a low spread that justifies its operation.

But it does not allow us to recover investment with all the volume that should be recovered. And it is true that the lower demand is – thermal production is suffering this lower demand in terms of construction that's within the prices, at two-thirds of our competitors and more than half of the investments are recovered. This gives us a certain state of calm. Of course, we have to be careful. But around 25 or 30 years ahead for the situation to improve, but this year and 2010 will not be years where the spreads are reaching 10, 12 or 15 as they were last year.

In any case, our thermal production compared to our competitors is quite small in Spain, as you know. Spreads are important, but our spread – with spread, so many of our competitors do depend strictly on those spreads.

Now in terms of the dividend, our intention is to maintain the payout. So we'll continue with the same levels of payout up until now. The results of the year, I said before, our expectations are that the result, before extraordinaries, it will be in line with last year, just slightly better actually. And it will depend on the extraordinaries, the different assets to see whether – what we'll – exactly what we'll have at the end of the year. I don't think that with the vision that we have right now, it is going to be very far from the results that we had last year, but it will depend as Pepé said, on the divestments being made now.

We still have to make it to see how another series of issues develops. Those are certain variables that are very difficult to predict. If the pound helps us, well then things will go well. The Real is helping us in the – but the pound doesn't seem to be working too well. So there's a certain number of variables that could affect things, either in one direction or another. We had a first half that went very well, as the financial director said, in terms of – but it has been negative in terms of exchange rates and there are different factors that could – but our policy is to maintain the same levels of debt as we've had around 57, 60, 59, in that range.

And another question, on the subject of the United States, to increase investment in 2012, will there be a capital increase in Iberdrola Renovables for those investments in the United States?

The last question, very easy, the answer is no. No, we're not going to have a capital increase in Iberdrola Renovables. And so that gets me to the first question, what will we do in the second half of the year? We'll do as much as we can. We've taken measures in terms of expenses, interim costs, from the point of view of prices as Paco talked about. So our vision for this second half is that prices are not going to get worse in the second half of the year, demand seems that it will improve in the second half of the year. As I spoke before, the cost of fuels, as Paco said, due to the reviews that we have, price reviews, will improve vis-à-vis the first half of the year and our fuel costs will improve. And more generally, what do you see as possibilities for maintaining or changing those companies' CapEx over the next couple of years? Then turning strictly to investment, the major investments at the desulphur of and other kinds of installation at Longannet finished, and we'll probably have to make decisions on some new combined cycle plant in forthcoming months. But they will never be within the next 12 months' expenditure. So we're not looking at more capital expenditure, maybe just maintenance. New York is really where 60 or 70% of their activities are. So our investment plans are to keep service going there in a regulated basis. But I will add that we are now negotiating Maine-Canada interconnection lines with Energy East. Now the return on investment there would be very, very good. Amparo has the figures. She knows the most.

This is a connection between Maine and Canada, a 1.5 billion investment. 12.5% return on equity to be begun next year, and will make it possible for increasing return on equity in 2012 and 2013. And that's – this is a major and extremely attractive project and we plan to invest heavily in it.
Would you like to answer the other question, Pepé?

Yes. The goal of between 25 and 26 billion means that we will continue with the disinvestment plan as announced. We announced 2.5 billion and we've achieved around 1.3 billion, which means that between the end of this year and early next year we will on the face of it conclude that plan, i.e. continue with divestments generically.
Paco, could you answer on gas?

As you know, we have a portfolio of around 7 BCMs. Next year it will be around seven or seven point something. We have three kinds of management here. Like everybody else, we're looking for price, but above all we're looking for flexibility. We've got a team permanently devoted to normal and extraordinary reviews of contract prices. Extraordinary, if required. And we're constantly negotiating flexibility conditions with the big producers, who are the people that sell to us.

We've bought nearly all of our gas from big producers. And they can be flexible because they've got the wells. That ties in with price. And we've got an operations team constantly seeking for opportunities to place and optimize the year's balance, and they try to tally supply with demand. And we're also seeking to diversify our scope to place gas, looking at gasifying – regasifying plants in markets other than Spain, such as the U.K. and the U.S.

We have the position in the regasification plant at Grange, which will probably come online in 2011, and also in two similar plants in the States. So we're looking to find as much flexibility as possible, so we can react briskly in any conditions, and otherwise it's going to be a matter of seeing it on a day-by-day basis.

Two points, gas suppliers in Spain. Well, they're all coming from the same place. Algeria is our big supplier. And I think the second supplier of Spain is Nigeria and then some from the Gulf. Now there are others here who know more about this than I do. Conrad, I'm looking at. So the review formulae are almost all identical. So for better or worse, we're all being treated in the same fashion. So the degree of competition in that area, as Paco said, has much more to do with flexibility in shifting the gas one way or another way than anything else. And we've shown year after year that we have that capacity.

Now correct me if I'm wrong, but we said that in 2009, 100% of our gas has been settled. We have no surplus. For next year, we've sold around or we've placed 90 something percent of the gas, between our own consumption, what we've sold with commercial contracts or what we've sold to – on a wholesale basis. And then there's a bit of margin. But as Paco said, it's good to have a bit of flexibility to play with. But essentially, it's all done and dusted. So there's no risk in that area. Next question? I don't know which person from this broker will be. I've got two names. If that's right, perhaps we could just hear from one of them.
Pablo Pena from BNI (sic) [BPI]

Garoña cost? None, as of now. Garoña is going to go on running until 2013. So no change. Our holding in Gamesa, we've said before that Gamesa is our main supplier of machinery, of plant and turbines. That's correct. Yes. Good morning everybody. Just one question remaining.
